metadata.title: Acalculia, Acquired
description: Acquired acalculia is the loss of numerical knowledge and calculation ability caused by injury to the brain and characterized by an inability to execute mathematical operations.(1) The ability to perform arithmetical operations and understand mathematical concepts requires multiple conceptual abilities and cognitive skills, including language, calculation abilities, spatial knowledge, memory, perceptual abilities, and executive functioning.(2) Therefore, brain damage that affects any one of these aspects of a person’s cognition can result in acalculia(2)
Acalculia that results from a primary deficit of mathematical/computational skills in isolation is called anarithmetria or anarithmia(2)

Acalculia often coexists with an acquired language disorder such as Broca’s aphasia or Wernicke’s aphasia or with acquired cognitive deficits such as a spatial disorder; however, it can also occur in isolation.(1,3,4) Despite the frequent co-occurrence  of aphasia and acalculia, the impairments of both receptive and expressive number processing and mathematical calculation are not necessarily due to language deficits(1,3,4)

Gerstmann syndrome is a specific collection of impairments that result from damage to the left angular gyrus and results in acalculia, written language impairment (agraphia), an inability to distinguish right from left, and finger agnosia.(1,5) In Gerstmann syndrome, acalculia occurs without aphasia(1)

presentation signs and symptoms: Possible deficits that result from acalculia include

Transcoding impairments(1) –In healthy individuals, numbers are represented in three distinct ways in the brain: a word or group of words (e.g., “twenty-nine”),  a set of Arabic numerals (e.g., 29), and as a cognitive representation of an abstract quantity that is independent from any symbols(1) –Transcoding refers to the ability to mentally translate these three representations of numbers(1)
Problems with quantitative magnitude representations (e.g., comparing two numbers to determine which is larger)(1)

Difficulty completing mental and/or written calculations and understanding arithmetical signs(1) –Difficulty retrieving arithmetical facts(1) –Loss of procedural arithmetic knowledge(1) –Impairment of any or all mathematical operations (i.e., addition, subtraction, multiplication, division)(6,7,8) -In a case study from Israel describing a 62-year-old patient with acalculia, authors found that despite an inability to add, multiply, or divide numbers, the patient’s ability to subtract was intact(6)
Difficulty reading or writing numbers(2) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: As with an evaluation, it is important to thoroughly review a patient’s medical records prior to any treatment

risk factors: Risk factors for acquired acalculia are related to the specific risk factors associated with the underlying cause of braindamage

overall contraindications precautions: See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: As with an evaluation, it is important to thoroughly review a patient’s medical records prior to any treatment

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: What is the underlying cause of acalculia? When did the patient present with acalculia? Review medical chart and physician reports to ascertain information regarding the patient’s diagnosis, medical treatments, and functional impairments

course of treatment.medical management: Document medical management of underlying diagnosis to date
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the physician has prescribed; are they being taken?
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Note the results of all diagnostic tests completed to date; specific tests completed will be determined by the underlying cause of acalculia
Diagnostic imaging (e.g., MRI, CT scan, chest X-ray)
Blood work (CBC, platelets, PT[INR], PTT, BUN, creatinine, glucose, urinalysis)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had speech, occupational, or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors  (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased) -Are there certain situations (e.g., when the patient is under pressure, attempting to do math in public) in which mathematical impairments are more pronounced? -Are there certain types of numbers, counting, math problems, operations, or mathematical concepts that are more or less difficult for the patient?(6)
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms -Transcoding impairments(1) -Problems with quantitative magnitude representations (e.g., comparing two numbers to determine which is larger)(1) -Difficulty completing mental and/or written calculations and understanding arithmetical signs(1) -Difficulty retrieving arithmetical facts(1) -Loss of procedural arithmetic knowledge(1) -Impairment of any or all mathematical operations (i.e., addition, subtraction, multiplication, division)(6,7,8) -Impairments of abstract mathematical concepts(1) -Difficulty reading and writing numbers(2)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms the patient is experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Note respiratory status -Does the patient require supplemental oxygen? Tracheostomy tube, nasal cannula, or breathing mask? -Does the patient require mechanical ventilation? -Does the patient become short of breath? If so, when? Standing? Walking? With exercise?Inquire about symptoms of depression (e.g., loss of interest in daily activities, problems sleeping, feelings of sadness and hopelessness) and refer to a neuropsychologist, clinical psychologist, or psychiatrist when present -If the patient has a concomitant language disorder (such as aphasia), there are many depression and psychological scales that have been used to assess patients with aphasia. A speech-language  pathologist (SLP) can collaborate with the psychologist to determine the appropriate evaluation with respect to the patient’s language abilities(16,17) -Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS) (mild aphasia)(17) -Depression Intensity Scale Circles (DISC) (moderate aphasia)(17) -Stroke Aphasic Depression Questionnaire (severe aphasia  to be completed by caregiver)(17) -Visual Analogue Self-Esteem  Scale(18)Document hearing ability -Does the patient have difficulty hearing in the quiet treatment environment? -Does the patient ask for frequent repetitions of words? -Does the patient have a known hearing loss? If so, does he or she wear hearing aids? Left, right, or bilateral? -It might be appropriate to recommend audiology consult for patients with suspected hearing loss Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe ___________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Document prior history of acalculia, cognitive deficit(s), and/or language disorder
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including overthe-counter  drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she is experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Is the patient employed? Does the patient require the use of mathematics for his or her job?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Functional limitations/assistance with ADLs/adaptive equipment -Note if patient wears hearing aids or glasses; determine if hearing aids are in working order -Note any use of wheelchair, walker, or communication devices -Document if the patient uses any adaptive equipment to communicate (e.g., pen/paper or high-tech alternative or augmentative [AAC] device)
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives (e.g., family members, caregivers). Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Document the use of AAC devices. For detailed information regarding the use of AAC devices for communication, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topicComplete a full oral mechanism examination; assess ROM, strength, endurance, and movement rate for the lips, tongue, and soft palate
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Assess spatial, number, and calculation skills with formal or informal measures(4) –Informal tests of mathematics/number skills -Reading Arabic numerals aloud(2) -Matching written Arabic numerals to actual quantities of items (pictured items or manipulatives)(15)  -Stating whether two quantities of items (pictured items or manipulatives) are the same or which group has more items(15) -Putting numbers in serial order(15) -Counting items (pictured items or manipulatives) aloud(15) -Counting forward, backward, by 2s, 5s, 10s(2) -Writing Arabic numerals to dictation(2,15) -Writing arithmetical signs to dictation (e.g., +, –,×, ÷, =)(2,15) -Performing simple calculations(2,15) -Mental and written calculations(2) -Performing complex calculations(2,15) -Comparing fractions; adding and subtracting with fractions(2) -Digit span assessments (immediate repetition of digit series forward and backward)(2) -Answering general numerical knowledge questions (e.g., How many minutes in an hour?)(2) -Solving word math problems(2) -Counting and using money(2)a standardized assessment composed of 13the patient is required to count phonologically, orthographically, and symbolically in Arabic numerals in automatic sequences of numbers forward, backward, and by ratios (e.g., by 2s, by 5s, by 10s)(3)the patient is asked to point to dots while counting aloud; evaluates ability to count discrete elements that are displayed in different spatial arrangements(3)the patient is asked to transcode between different combinations of phonological representations (number spoken aloud), Arabic numerals, and orthographic codes (written words)(3)the patient is asked to write to dictation and name the arithmetical signs(3)the patient is asked to point to the larger of two numbers presented in Arabic numerals and orthographic form(3)the patient is required to perform mental calculations of simple operations; computations are given to the patient either orally or in written form(3)the patient is asked to estimate the correct answer for complex operations(3)the patient is shown a vertical line graded from 0 to 100 and is asked to place a spoken or written Arabic numeral on the line in one of three possible positions(3)the patient is asked to copy a set of 2- or 3-digit  numbers and place them in an appropriate way for the arithmetical sign provided(3)the patient is required to perform written calculations of addition, subtraction, and multiplication(3)the patient is asked to give an estimation of weight, length, or numerosity of objects in a picture(3)the patient is provided with a situation and asked to give an interpretation of the numbers (e.g., a class of 9 children; is that number of children too low, average, or too high?)(3)the patient is asked questions that relate to numerical knowledge of specific facts such as how many months are in 1 year(3) –Number Processing and Calculation (NPC) battery(13) –Arithmetic subtest of the Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale—Fourth Edition (WAIS-IV)(2)
relevant tests and measures.speech and language examination: Speech and language examination (including reading)A motor speech evaluation should be performed if there are signs of coexisting apraxia or dysarthria -For detailed information on assessment and treatment of apraxia, see Clinical Review…Apraxia of Speech (Acquired) ;T708586 -For detailed information on assessment and treatment of dysarthria (spastic, flaccid, ataxic, hypokinetic, and hyperkinetic), see the series of Clinical Reviews on these topicsComplete informal and standardized assessments of receptive and expressive language as indicated; aphasia commonly co-occurs  with acalculia(1,3) -For detailed information on aphasia, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topicAssess vocal quality and other appropriate voice parameters (e.g., intensity, pitch, range); neurological impairment can affect vocal quality; if necessary, refer to otolaryngologist (ENT) to rule out laryngeal pathology -For detailed information on voice disorders, see the series of Clinical Reviews on these topicsRule out or identify atypical speech disfluencies (stuttering) -For detailed information on disorders of fluency, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topicAssess reading and writing skills; patients with acalculia can have difficulty reading and writing Arabic numerals and orthographic forms of numbers(3,15,19) -Impairments of reading as they relate to acalculia -Difficulty recognizing spatial orientation of numbers(19) -Inversions of numbers(19) -Left neglect; failing to read the number(s) on the far left(19) -Difficulty following lines of numbers when performing mathematical operations(19) -Impairments of writing as they relate to acalculia -Incorrect formation of the numeral(19) -Writing an extra, erroneous number(19) -Incorrect use of spaces to join or split numbers(19) -Increasing the left margins(19) -For detailed information on both alexia (acquired reading impairment) and agraphia (acquired writing impairment), see the series of Clinical Reviews on these topics
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Individuals with acalculia often have other cognitive deficits as a result of the underlying brain damage.(1,3) Document the results of any cognitive or neuropsychological testing that has been completed. Complete cognitive-linguistic  assessment with formal and/or informal measures as indicated  –Patients with visuospatial or visuoconstructive impairments will likely have difficulty with written calculations due to difficulty aligning digits(1,19) -Acalculia that is the result of spatial deficits in which the rules for writing digits in the proper position and alignment of numbers are not followed is referred to as spatial acalculia(19) –Patients with visuospatial neglect can leave out the leftmost digit when performing written calculations(1) –Patients with impaired short-term  memory might have difficulty performing mental calculations(1)
relevant tests and measures.swallow examination: Assess swallowing function if there are concerns about swallowing. For detailed information on dysphagia, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic
relevant tests and measures.tracheostomy examination: If present, assess tracheostomy tube and document date of placement, current respiratory status, and use of speaking valve. For detailed information on assessment of a tracheostomy tube and use of a speaking valve, see Clinical Review…Passy-Muir  Tracheostomy & Ventilator Swallowing and Speaking Valve ; CINAHL Topic IDT708919

other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Patients with this diagnosis might be at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention  instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention  strategies

To ensure relevance and appropriateness of treatment programs, decisions about goals and course of therapy should be made in collaboration with the patient, caregivers, and other healthcare professionals. It is highly recommended that family members be involved in the rehabilitation process as much as possible
Clinician should carefully consider the patient’s stamina and medical status before beginning therapy
Cultural background, language preference, and patient interests must be considered when planning treatment goals and activities
Precautions will vary according to the individual patient and the severity of accompanying language, cognitive, behavioral, and/or motor symptoms

Patients with acalculia might be at risk for aspiration and penetration of oral intake. Ensure that the patient and family/ caregivers are aware of potential aspiration risks and are educated about strategies when appropriate

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary presented below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: A patient with acalculia might benefit from speech therapy to address the underlying cognitive and language deficits that contribute to the difficulty in mathematical and numerical processing abilities
assessment plan of care.rule out: The patient’s medical team will rule out possible causes of the acalculia in order to determine the underlying brain condition that is responsible for these deficits
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Referrals should be made to physical and occupational therapy if there appears to be an underlying motor or muscle control/strength deficit Referral to neurology should be made for a full neurological workup in the case of a patient who presents with an acalculia with no known underlying cause Referral to psychology, psychiatry, or neuropsychology should be made if the patient reports feelings of depression, hopelessness, or other emotional distress Referral to ophthalmology should be made if patient appears to have visual field cut or poor vision Referral to audiology should be made to identify or rule out hearing loss, if appropriate
treatment summary: Recommended treatment approaches for acalculia include: –massive practice using drills of arithmetic facts and math problems(1,2) –errorless learning of math problems progressing from simple to complex(1) –retraining of abstract arithmetic concepts and numerical knowledge(1,2) –combined training of procedural and conceptual mathematical information(1) –functional activities using math concepts (e.g., time, money, distance)(2) –using principles of aphasia therapy to relearn underlying rules of mathematics(1,21) -Some researchers consider acalculia to be a type of aphasia for the language of mathematics(21) . maintenance or prevention: Maintenance of math skills in an individual with acalculia will depend on continued use of skills obtained in therapy; the extent to which the patient is able to maintain these skills/prevent further decline will vary with respect to the degree of the underlying acalculia and concomitant cognitive/language impairments
For treatments that involve drills, patients will likely maintain progress made if they continue to utilize the home programs following discharge from therapy
